chapter: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following arteries is most commonly involved in patients with coronary artery 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The left anterior descending (anterior interventricular) coronary artery is most commonly 
involved in coronary artery disease (CAD) or coronary heart disease or ischemic heart disease. The regions affected are the anterior wall of the left ventricle near the apex and the anterior 
portion of the ventricular septum. CAD is caused by plaque buildup in the walls of the coronary arteries that narrow over time and 
can partially or totally block the blood flow causing myocardial ischemia and subsequently 
infarction. The image below shows coronary circulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 2: Which area of the myocardium is most vulnerable to damage in patients with ischemic heart 
disease?
questions.explanation:
Subendocardium is the region of the myocardium most vulnerable to ischemic damage. The myocardium is perfused from the epicardium to the endocardium. This results in the 
subendocardium being the least perfused region making it most vulnerable to ischemic damage. A narrow zone of the myocardium immediately beneath the endocardium is spared from necrosis 
because it can be oxygenated by diffusion from the ventricle. 947 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in 
pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac 
troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior 
descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, 
descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in 
patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial 
leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated. These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction. The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and 
V5 in Wellens syndrome. Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 948 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse. Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 4: 940 
Sold by @itachibot In a patient with suspected stable angina, which of the following findings are likely to be 
present?

options.a: CK-MB is elevated ; Troponin T is normal
options.b: Troponin I is elevated ; Myoglobin is normal
options.c: Myoglobin is elevated ; CK-MB is normal
options.d: Troponin I is normal ; CK-MB is normal

questions.explanation:
The levels of cardiac markers remain unchanged in stable and unstable angina as there is no 
necrosis of cardiac myocytes. The clinical presentations of ischemic heart disease can be broadly classified into: • Chronic coronary syndrome (CCS) - this includes • Stable angina - this is an episodic angina that occurs with predictable severity, frequency, and 
threshold of precipitation by stressors, and is relieved by rest and nitrates • Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) - this includes • Unstable angina - this is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an ACS with no 
elevation of biomarkers • Myocardial infarction - it is the necrosis and death of a portion of the myocardium due to 
prolonged ischemia. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in this condition
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 5: While evaluating a patient with chest pain in the emergency, you ask him to localize the 
sensation. He places a hand over the sternum with a clenched fist. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation:
When a patient with angina is asked to localize the sensation, he or she typically places a hand 
over the sternum, sometimes with a clenched fist, to indicate a squeezing, central, substernal 
discomfort. This is called Levine’s sign. Option A: Mayne's sign- Drop of at least 15 mmHg in the diastolic blood pressure on raising the 
arm. It occurs in patients with aortic regurgitation (not reliable). Option C: Frank’s sign- Diagonal crease in the ear lobe indicative of cardiovascular diseases and/or 
diabetes. Option D: Friedreich's sign- Exaggerated drop in JVP seen in constrictive pericarditis.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 6: A 60-year-old woman presents with chest discomfort, associated with a squeezing sensation 
in the substernal area. She added that it was precipitated by physical activity and relieved on 
taking rest. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of stable angina in which the pain is usually 
crescendo-decrescendo in nature. Characteristic features of pain in stable angina: • Squeezing, central, substernal discomfort • Crescendo-decrescendo in nature • Typically lasts 2 to 5 min 949 
Sold by @itachibot • Can radiate occasionally to neck, jaw, epigastrium, shoulders, left arm. Angina is rarely localized below the umbilicus or above the mandible. Myocardial ischemic 
discomfort does not radiate to the trapezius muscles, that radiation pattern is more typical of 
pericarditis. Features

questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient presented with angina and ECG showed ST-segment elevation. The pulse rate was 
found to be 54 beats/min and blood pressure was 98/56 mm Hg. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of STEMI with bradycardia which is a feature of inferior wall 
myocardial infarction. Up to one-half with inferior infarction show evidence of parasympathetic 
hyperactivity (bradycardia and/or hypotension). 950 
Sold by @itachibot Many patients have a normal pulse rate and blood pressure within the first hour of STEMI. About one-fourth of patients with anterior infarction have manifestations of sympathetic nervous 
system hyperactivity (tachycardia and/or hypertension).
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 8: A patient was admitted with acute MI. During a daily examination, a transient murmur was 
heard. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.explanation:
A transient midsystolic or late systolic apical murmur due to mitral regurgitation secondary to 
dysfunction of the mitral valve apparatus (papillary muscle dysfunction, LV dilation) may be 
present in STEMI.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following cardiac biomarkers is the earliest to rise after acute myocardial 
infarction?
questions.explanation:
Myoglobin is the earliest to rise in acute MI followed by troponin, CK-MB and then LDH. Serum myoglobin and heart-type fatty acid-binding protein are smaller molecules that diffuse 
through interstitial ■uids more rapidly after cell death than the larger CK and troponin molecules. 
They become abnormal as early as 30 minutes after myocardial injury. Neither molecule is 
specific to myocardial tissue. Myoglobin levels are not tested in routine practice.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient is under evaluation for acute MI. Which of the following biomarkers would you 
prefer to test for?
questions.explanation:
The most preferred cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI amongst the given options 
is cardiac troponin-I. Cardiac troponin-I, CK-MB, and myoglobin are significantly more specific for acute-MI than 
cardiac troponin-T. The cardiac troponins are particularly valuable when there is clinical suspicion of a small MI that 
may be below the detection limit for CK-MB measurement. They have replaced CK-MB as the 
biomarker of choice for diagnosing myocardial infarction. Cardiac troponins: • Most specific cardiac biomarker for myocardial injury/acute MI • Elevations are useful for short & long-term prognoses in MI • Elevations correlate with the estimation of infarct size and risk of death • Newer highly sensitive assays for troponins become positive within the first 3 hours after onset 
of chest pain in MI
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question: Question 11: Elevated cardiac troponins may not be seen in which of the following patients?

options.b: A 65-year-old woman suffering from Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
options.c: A patient who underwent cardioversion for VT in the emergency room

questions.explanation:
951 
Sold by @itachibot Troponins are not elevated in patients suffering from angina. Troponins are elevated in the case of 
myocardial necrosis (seen in MI) whereas angina is associated with myocardial 
insufficiency/ischemia. Conditions associated with an elevation in cardiac troponins: • MI • Myocarditis • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy • Myocardial contusion • Cardioversion/defibrillation • LV strain from CHF • Hypertensive crisis • RV strain from PE • Renal disease • Sepsis
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following biomarkers is preferred for diagnosing reinfarction in a patient 
post-NSTEMI?
questions.explanation:
Troponin(serial) is the preferred biomarker for diagnosing reinfarction. Serial troponin levels are used to detect reinfarction, an acute MI that occurs within 28 days of an 
incident or recurrent MI. In case of suspected reinfarction, an immediate measurement of cardiac troponin followed by a 
second sample after 3-6 hours. 20 percent rise in the second sample suggests reinfarction.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following is likely to be seen in a patient diagnosed with acute myocardial 
infarction?

options.a: Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 2 < 1 in plasma
options.b: Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 2 > 1 in plasma
options.c: Ratio of LDH 1 / LDH 4 < 1 in plasma
options.d: Ratio of LDH 2 / LDH 1 > 1 in plasma

questions.explanation:
In myocardial injury, the LDH-1 fraction increases, and the ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 becomes 
>1 in the plasma. This is called flipped LDH pattern. Normally, the LDH-2 fraction is greater than the LDH-1 fraction in the plasma, and therefore, the 
ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 is normally <1.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 14: What is the maximum predicted heart rate in a 50-year-old gentleman on exercise tolerance 
test?
questions.explanation:
Maximum predicted heart rate on an exercise tolerance test (treadmill test) is given by: HRmax = 
220 – Age So in a 50-year-old male, the maximum predicted heart rate is 220 - 50 = 170 bpm. 952 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a contraindication for performing an exercise tolerance test?

options.d: AAA with transverse diameter of 5.5 cm

questions.explanation:
Treadmill exercise testing (treadmill test) may be safely performed in patients with an abdominal 
aortic aneurysm. Absolute contraindications to exercise testing: • Acute myocardial infarction (within 2 days) • High-risk unstable angina • Uncontrolled cardiac arrhythmia with hemodynamic compromise • Active endocarditis • Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis • Decompensated heart failure • Acute pulmonary embolism or pulmonary infarction • Acute myocarditis or pericarditis • Severe pulmonary hypertension • Aortic dissection Relative Contraindications to exercise testing: • Known left main coronary artery stenosis • Moderate aortic stenosis with uncertain relation to symptoms • Tachyarrhythmias with uncontrolled ventricular rates • Acquired complete heart block • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with severe resting gradient • Mental impairment with limited ability to cooperate
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following drugs cannot be used for a patient undergoing stress 
echocardiography?
questions.explanation:
Phenylephrine, an alpha-receptor agonist, cannot be used for a patient undergoing stress 
echocardiography as it causes vasoconstriction. Dobutamine (preferred agent) and vasodilators (dipyridamole, adenosine, regadenoson) are used 
for pharmacological stress echocardiography. Pharmacologic stress testing is used in those who cannot exercise because of pulmonary 
veno-occlusive disease, musculoskeletal disease, or exertional dyspnea. Stress echocardiography can be done using either exercise (e.g.: treadmill test or bicycle test) or 
pharmacologic agents. 953 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following findings during an exercise tolerance test is not associated with 
multivessel coronary artery disease?

options.b: Persistence of ST segment changes late into recovery phase
options.c: Failure to increase systolic BP by at least 20mmHg

questions.explanation:
A failure to increase systolic blood pressure by 10 mm Hg, or a sustained decrease in systolic 
blood pressure of 10 mm Hg or more, is suggestive of multivessel (or left main) CAD. Other abnormalities on exercise testing that are suggestive of multivessel CAD include: • Early-onset of ischemic ST-segment depression • ST-segment depression of 2 mm (0.2mV) involving 5 or more leads, or persisting 5 minutes 
into recovery • Exercise-induced ST-segment elevation is also consistent with multivessel CAD • Recent evidence suggests that ST-segment elevation of 1 mm in lead aVR may be a significant 
predictor of left main coronary artery disease, proximal left anterior descending (LAD) artery 
disease, or at least multivessel CAD An exercise tolerance/treadmill test involves walking in place on a treadmill while monitoring the 
electrical activity of your heart. Throughout the test, the speed and incline of the treadmill 
increase. The results show how well your heart responds to the stress of different levels of 
exercise.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following compounds is used for myocardial perfusion imaging?
questions.explanation:
Myocardial perfusion imaging is done with either thallium-201 or technetium-99m labeled 
compounds (e.g., technetium-99m sestamibi).
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient is being considered for CABG in order to achieve coronary revascularization. Which 
of the following test will not be useful to assess myocardial viability for predicting the risk of 944 
Sold by @itachibot perioperative morbidity?
questions.explanation: Modalities for the determination of myocardial viability include: • Thallium-201 imaging • MRI • Dobutamine echocardiography • PET scan (investigation of choice) The investigation of choice for assessing the ventricular function is cardiac MRI.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 20: Which questionnaire is used for the assessment of a patient who presented with symptoms of 
angina?
questions.explanation:
WHO Rose questionnaire is used for the assessment of angina. Option B: International prostate symptom score (IPSS) questionnaire is used for BPH. Option C: The CAGE questionnaire is used to check for signs of possible alcohol dependency. 954 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: The youth tobacco survey (YTS) questionnaire is used to study the prevalence of use of 
tobacco products amongst youth.
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following ECG findings is first to appear in a patient suspected of acute 
myocardial infarction?
questions.explanation:
During acute myocardial infarction, the ECG evolves through 3 stages: • T-wave peaking and T-wave inversion: • Peaked T-wave aka hyperacute T-wave- first ECG change (occurs within minutes) • If the blood flow is restored or the oxygen demands of the heart are met, the T waves will revert 
to normal • If myocardial cell death has occurred, T wave inversions appear (over days) and persist for 
months to years. • A nonspecific finding and is indicative only of ischemia and not diagnostic of infarction • ST-segment elevation occurs over minutes to hours (after T-wave peaking) • The appearance of new pathologic Q-waves: • Occurs over hours to days (after ST-segment elevation) and is indicative of an evolving MI • The persistence of pathological Q-waves indicates irreversible myocardial cell death
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best 
investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.explanation:
Measurement of troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours. 955 
Sold by @itachibot Troponin T/I: • Highly specific for MI • Troponin I is more important than troponin T. • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days. • This makes troponins a superior marker for diagnosing MI in the recent past (late diagnosis). • Reinfarction: It is now clear that cardiac troponin (cTn) increases rapidly, even if it is from an 
abnormal baseline in patients with reinfarction. • Sometimes cTn concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected 
reinfarction. In this case, the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the 
cTn measurement Creatine kinase (CK): • Less sensitive and specific than troponins • When cTn is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): • Normally, LDH2>LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1>LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio. • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI. Myoglobin: • Earliest enzyme to increase after MI. • Not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle. Heart-type fatty acid-binding protein (H-FABP), which mainly exists in cardiomyocytes, has 
recently emerged as a potential biomarker, which was found to be sensitive for the early diagnosis 
of acute myocardial infarction. H-FABP as an early marker and cTnI as a late marker would be the 
ideal combination to cover the complete diagnostic window for AMI 956 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following conditions is not associated with an ST-segment elevation?
questions.explanation:
There is no ST-segment elevation in unstable angina. Differential diagnosis of ST-segment elevation (Mnemonic-ELEVATION): • Electrolytes(Hypercalcemia, Hyperkalemia) • Left bundle branch block • Early(Benign) repolarization, Embolism(Acute pulmonary) • Ventricular hypertrophy • Arrhythmia(Brugada syndrome), Aneurysm of LV, Aortic dissection, Antiarrhythmic drugs(Class 
1c) • Tako-tsubo syndrome, Tumor invading left ventricle, Trauma to ventricles • Infarction(MI), Inflammation(Myocarditis, Pericarditis) • Osborn J waves (Hypothermia or hypercalcemia) • Non-atherosclerotic vasospasm(Prinzmetal's angina) 957 
Sold by @itachibot Ischemic Heart Disease - Complications and Management
questions.chapter_heading: Ischemic Heart Disease - Presentation and Diagn
